Award.AwardTitle: AF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Optimality in Homology - Algorithms and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many applications in science and engineering encounter the problem of
identifying and processing topologically interesting features in the
digital representation of a geometry or data. Such features often need
to be optimal with respect to some metric (measurement). It is
recognized that homology groups from algebraic topology play an
essential role in these computations. Although the study of structural
properties of the homology groups has a rich history in mathematics,
their computations in combination with geometry are not that well
studied. The principal investigators (PIs) propose to study these
fundamental questions thoroughly, along with their connections to
practical problems from science and engineering.
Intellectual merit: Efficient solutions of the optimality questions in
homology computations require both mathematical and algorithmic
developments. The PIs bring aboard these required expertise. Apart
from the synergistic effect of the proposed study on mathematics and
theoretical computer science, the close ties with various applications
in science and engineering will play a synergistic role between
computational fields such as computer graphics, computer vision,
sensor networks, computer aided design, and scientific fields such as
biology, physics, chemistry, and others.

Optimization of aspects of homology groups provides
important insights in many scientific and engineering applications
ranging from tunnels in protein molecules to voids in large
machines. Solutions of such problems can aid in the manufacturing of
better machines, designing of new drugs, and rapid modeling of
customized objects. The educational impact of this project is in a
large synergy between mathematics and computer science motivated by
real applications. Course notes, internet distributions, and software
systems developed through the project will enable the scientific
community to study challenging problems in geometry, topology, and
algorithms. Graduate students supported by the project will develop
skills in mathematics and theoretical computer science and also in
writing robust, efficient, and user-friendly software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the roles of field of topology in mathematics and applications is to classify and distinguish shapes of objects and structures. Geometry is another such tool for studying shapes. For some purposes, topology is more flexible than geometry because measurements such as lengths, areas and volumes usually don't play a role in topology. In some applications however, geometry and topology both become important. As an example of this, imagine a channel in a cell membrane. This channel is a topological feature which also has some geometric characteristics. For example, a measurement of the narrowest part of such a channel might be important for understanding what molecules or ions (charged atoms or molecules) can go through the channel. In these types of situations topology and geometry are both important. Typically these situations require one to zero in on some optimal aspect of the geometry in a specific topological feature. Searching for this optimal geometric feature while focusing on just the given topological feature is a challenging problem. It requires optimizing a geometric quantity subject to a topological constraint. Typical optimization methods do not come with a language for expressing the constraints of topology. The translation from topology to optimization language has to be done algebraically. In this project we developed algorithms, theory and software for expressing and solving such optimization problems with topological constraints. We combined techniques that are typically used in physical modeling with techniques from optimization to create such algorithms. During the course of the project we trained four graduate and five undergraduate students, some of whom have gone on to work in software industry and academic research.
